Members of the public may address the Board on any subject not on tonight’s agenda; however, provisions of the Brown Act (Government Code Section 54954.2(a) and 54954.3) preclude any action.  As an unagendized item, no response is required from the Board or District staff and no action can be taken; however, the Board may instruct the Superintendent to agendize the item for a future meeting.
	 
Any person may address the Board on any item on the meeting agenda.  Persons wishing to address the Board must fill out a gold request form, which is located at the entrance of the Board Room. When your name is called, please come to the podium, state your name for the record, and limit your remarks to three (3) minutes.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  5.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and André Bell, Assistant Director of Capital Accounting and Purchasing
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Total School Solutions Bond Audit Update
	 
	 
Total School Solutions performed a Facilities Program Management Review on Measures G and E for Fiscal Years 2009–10 through 2011–12 and a Performance audit of Measures G and E for Fiscal Year 2012-13.  The purpose of this presentation is to update the Board on the audit findings and to update the Board on the Capital Accounting Program transition.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  5.03
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Robert Ball, Program Manager, SGI Construction Management, Inc.
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and/or Discussion regarding the Bond Program Update
	 
In 2002, voters in the East Side Union High School District approved Bond Measure G in the amount of $298 million for the purpose of modernizing existing school facilities and building new facilities to support the changing needs of education in the District. A substantial portfolio of projects has been completed under Measure G, which is concluding with a district-wide site improvement initiative, currently underway.
	 
In 2008, voters in the District approved Bond Measure E in the amount of $349 million for the purpose of continuing the modernization of existing school facilities and building new facilities.  With the exception of three projects currently in construction, two in the construction contract bidding phase, and one in design, all Measure E projects have been completed.
	 
In 2012, voters in the District approved Bond Measure I in the amount of $120 million, allowing the school modernization program to expand its impact to support the changing needs of education in the District.  Some school sites have Measure E project savings, which supplements their Measure I allocations on their approved new projects.
	 
An update on the status of the District’s Bond Program is presented for discussion.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  5.04
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Robert Ball, Program Manager, SGI Construction Management, Inc.
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and/or Discussion regarding the Unfunded Projects and Funding Gap
	 
The East Side community of voters has generously supported school modernization general obligation bond measures G, E, and I in the past twelve years.  The school modernization projects completed to-date have made a positive impact in the learning environment.  While that impact has made a significant difference in the lives of the students who have experienced those modernized learning facilities, there remains school facilities that have not received the benefit of modernization due to funding constraints.  
	 
Facilities planning staff identified the school modernization funding gap and have projected the impact of escalating construction costs in the foreseeable future.  This information is being presented to the Board for the discussion.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  5.05
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Julio Lucas, District Architect
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and/or Discussion regarding the Alternative Education and Charter School Education Space Planning
	 
The District currently has Proposition 39 Facilities Use Agreements with six charter schools.  Four of those Agreements are single-year arrangements that expire on June 30, 2015.  The District anticipates Proposition 39 facilities petitions from additional charter schools for fiscal year 2015-16 and beyond.  It is in the District’s best interest to consider long-term housing accommodations for charter schools.  In addition, there are East Side alternative education programs with unmet facilities requirements.
	 
Facilities planning staff developed alternative education housing accommodation options to address these needs and has reviewed them with Superintendent’s Council.  After thoughtful consideration, the best options were identified and are presented for discussion.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  5.06
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and/or Discussion regarding the Proposed Interior and Exterior Improvements at the Education Center
	 
The Education Center site was designed in 1976, and constructed thereafter.  In the early to mid 1990’s, components that had reached the ends of their service lives were replaced, including mechanical system replacement, exterior painting, reroofing, parking lot asphalt, and carpet replacement.  In the late 2000’s, interior lighting was retrofit for energy efficiency.  Other than those component repairs or replacements, no significant modernization work has taken place. 
	 
The buildings are now in need of wood siding repairs and repainting.  There are a few areas of asphalt concrete needing deep lift repair, and all areas require recoating to maintain the integrity of the asphalt.  In addition, strategic entry improvements are needed to provide a refreshed, welcoming entry experience.  
	 
Exterior improvements are presented for discussion.
